facts.text: Strained relationship between accused and deceased: In December 1963, Kudrat (husband of Jinnatbai) was murdered; Sobal Singh (deceased) prosecuted but acquitted.

On morning of 26th February 1966, seven accused started from house of Sohrab: Jinnatbai with son and Nadar in chhakda driven by Gaburia; Ismail, Bashir, Sardar on bicycles; Sohrab on mare with unlicensed revolver.
Jinnatbai handed unlicensed gun to Nadar, kept in chhakda.
Shortly before, Sobal Singh left Solsindhi for Sanwer on foot with Chhogia, followed by Madhosingh, Kishandas, Kana, Bhawarsingh in chhakda.
Near village Maharajganj, accused overtook the two groups and went ahead; Sohrab turned mare, chased Sobal Singh across fields in mouza Ranwer; Chhogia ran away.
Sohrab fired revolver at Sobal Singh several times, caught him by shirt which came off; dismounted mare; Nadar ran with double-barrelled shot-gun, handed to Sohrab, caught Sobal Singh.
Sohrab fired gun at Sobal Singh; both Sobal Singh and Nadar fell; Nadar got up; Sohrab fired again at Sobal Singh lying face up.
Bashir and Sardar ran to spot, struck Sobal Singh with knives; Sobal Singh died on spot from cumulative effect.
Accused went to chhakda; Jinnatbai asked if man dead; told Kudrat avenged.
Within one hour, Madhosingh (deceased's father, eyewitness) reported at Sanwar police station (1.5 miles away); FIR issued.
Police seized from spot and vicinity: used/unused shotgun/revolver ammunition, shirt, stirrup with strap piece.
After Bashir's statement, two knives recovered from trunk of date palm tree near Bhaori-Deorakhedi border.
Sohrab pointed out place on Bhaori-Deorakhedi border where he broke revolver and gun, cut/burnt wooden components; firearm parts recovered.
Divers recovered disjointed/mutilated firearm parts, cartridges from river Kshipra bottom near that place.
Saddle (missing stirrup/strap) from house of Darvesh (Sohrab's maternal uncle); strap matched scene strap.
Deceased's payjama and two knives sent to Chemical Examiner/Serologist: blood on one knife, could not confirm human.
Autopsy: Death from internal haemorrhage/shock due to gunshot wounds/injuries to liver, spleen, lungs.
Nadar operated twice; five bullets extracted (three left hand, two right); identified as gun shots.
Ballistic expert: Hole in recovered shirt caused by .38 revolver; shots from body were gun pellets, not revolver bullets.
Sessions Judge acquitted all seven accused.

State appealed to High Court (Criminal Appeal No. 26 of 1967); High Court maintained acquittal of five (Jinnatbai, Gaburia, Ismail, Sardar, Bashir), convicted Sohrab and Nadar under 302/34 IPC (life imprisonment) and 25-A Arms Act (1 year RI, concurrent).
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave/certificate.
Accused denied guilt; stated death not caused by them.

Sessions Judge found: Chase on horse, revolver firing, shirt pull fabrication; shirt hole not linked to Sohrab (pellets not revolver); disbelieved PW1 Madhosingh, PW2 Arjun, PW6 Kishandas, PW31 Babulal; most incised injuries postmortem; no belief in stabbing by Bashir/Sardar.
Sessions Judge: Injuries suggest shooter lower than victim or victim bending/kneeling (not supported); Nadar pellets not as per witnesses.
High Court: Contradictions minor; Nadar palm injuries from protecting against gunfire; incised wounds likely postmortem; pistol story myth, discarded.
High Court: Unanimity that Sohrab fired fatal gun shot(s) handed by Nadar; corroborated by medical; rejected accidental firing defence.

Appellant Sohrab's statement u/s 342: Started 7 AM to court on mare; Nadar etc in cart; dispute with Chhogya; heard gun fire, saw Nadar running north chased by Sobal Singh loading gun; struggled, gun fired, Sobal fell; dropped gun, fired again; saw Nadar bleeding; hid then surrendered.

Appellant Nadar's statement: Going to court; Sohrab ahead on mare; Sobal Singh/Chhogya behind with gun; Nadar urinating, first shot hit hands, fell face up; second missed; ran to cart, to Sanwer, sent sister-in-law, beaten at PS, report not recorded.
FIR by Madhosingh: Saw Sohrab catch Sobal; Nadar bring gun, catch Sobal; Sohrab fire back, Sobal fall, second fire; Sardar/Bashir knife blows; went to cart.

legal_issues.text: Whether Sohrab and Nadar are guilty of murder under Section 302/34 IPC based on prosecution evidence, despite Sessions Judge acquittal, considering contradictions, medical evidence, and defence version.
Scope of High Court's power in appeal against acquittal under Sections 417, 418, 423 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution story of chase on mare, revolver firing, shirt pull is fabrication; shirt hole from revolver but body pellets from gun.
Disbelieved eyewitnesses PW1,2,6,31; most incised injuries postmortem; no stabbing by Bashir/Sardar.
Medical evidence: Injuries suggest shooter lower than victim (no bending/kneeling); Nadar injuries not as per witnesses; pistol integral, unsafe to believe.
High Court agreed on contradictions, pistol myth, postmortem wounds but still convicted; in appeal against acquittal, must consider trial court reasons.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor; Sanwant Singh v. State of Rajasthan; Agarwal v. State of Maharashtra

petitioner_arguments.text: Defence: Accidental firing in scuffle with Sobal Singh who had gun.

respondent_arguments.text: Unanimity in eyewitnesses that Nadar handed gun to Sohrab who fired fatal shots; corroborated by medical (gunshot wounds), FIR, recoveries.
Contradictions minor (spot, fields, manner); Nadar injuries from gunfire protection; details from distance are inferences, broad facts visible.
Defence accidental firing rejected; incompatible with medical, statements.

court_reasoning.text: Sessions Judge and High Court agreed on embellishments (pistol, chase details, stabbing) but broad features credible: parties in field, Sohrab on mare chased, Nadar handed gun, Sohrab fired causing death and Nadar injury.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrepancies do not discard entire evidence; sift truth after caution; falsus in uno falsus in omnibus not rule.

court_reasoning.text: High Court reviewed evidence at large, gave weight to trial views, presumption of innocence, etc., as per precedents; considered Sessions reasons but found overwhelming evidence on core facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court power full under CrPC; expressed reasons for reversal.

court_reasoning.text: FIR names core roles of Sohrab/Nadar; accused statements admit presence, gun firing in their hands, Nadar injury; defence scuffle accidental rejected as Sessions/High Court disbelieved, incompatible with medical.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accused versions lend credence to prosecution core.

court_reasoning.text: No justification linking specific entry/exit wounds; no probe; positions indeterminable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Medical does not negate deliberate firing by Sohrab.

holdings.text: Sohrab and Nadar guilty under Section 302/34 IPC; Sohrab fired gun deliberately at Sobal Singh handed by Nadar.
High Court justified in reversing acquittal after full review.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheo Swarup and Ors. v. King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court power in appeal against acquittal: review evidence at large, reverse if warranted, give weight to trial views etc.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sanwant Singh v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Adopts Sheo Swarup principles for appellate approach in acquittal appeals.
No curtailment of appellate powers; consider all record, express reasons.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Murder with common intention applied to Sohrab and Nadar.

statutes_cited.name: Arms Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction for unlicensed arms, 1 year RI concurrent.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Statement u/s 342; High Court appellate powers against acquittal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court confirmed High Court judgment convicting Sohrab and Nadar under Section 302/34 IPC (life imprisonment) and Section 25-A Arms Act (1 year RI concurrent), dismissing appeal against acquittal reversal.

key_quotes.text: "falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule for the reason that hardly one comes across a witness whose evidence does not contain a grain of untruth or at any rate exaggeration, embroideries or embellishments."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies accepting core prosecution evidence despite discrepancies.

key_quotes.text: "The unassailable story therefore remains is that Sohrab fired a gun at Sobal Singh and Nadar handed over the gun to him. Both of them are therefore guilty."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court conclusion on guilt adopted by Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "In this view, we confirm the judgment of the High Court and dismiss the appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
